head.supplied: Brown's Camp ¶ 9/4/89. ¶ […] ¶ ¶ I write late at night regarding the alleged E. stricta. In my last letter I have mentioned already, that I consider Baron von Mullers fresh determination a mistake, a...

div.p: MRS 203, Inwards correspondence — special bundles, 1886-1921 Item 1, 89/147, Archives of the Powerhouse Museum, Sydney.

I write late at night regarding the alleged E. stricta. In my last letter I have mentioned already, that I consider Baron von Mullers fresh determination a mistake, and as for Euc. Gunnii, the species in question is widely different from the species he determined for me as E. Gunnii in summer or autumn of 1885 before I went to New Guinea, and of which I forwarded specimens to you in 1887, as well as bark, log and

1. I remember distinctly that when I recieved
sic.
the Baron's determination at the time, as E. stricta
specific name partly obscured by ink blot.
I was rather vexed with myself, for not knowing it again, as I had passed E. stricta already on the top of the Budawang Mntn in the Braidwood district, having been under the impression then that I had never seen that species before . (the species from Tingiringi)

2. If the Baron's determination had then been E. Gunnii , I would surely have drawn his attention to the fact, that this species is entirely unlike the species he determined for me as such in summer or autumn of 1885.
Neither leaves buds or fruit resemble the leaves, buds and fruit of the species which Baron von Muller determined for me

in 1885 as E. goniocalyx from Bonang. […]
Not relevant. Perhaps I should also say that I saw E. Gunnii for the first time in 1885 at Haydon's Bog a few miles from Delegate, and from there I obtained the specimens which Baron von Muller determined for me at the time. At that time I was staying with an old splitter and fencer, who showed me the different timbers in the bush, and he used to tell me that some people call this Gum (E. Gunnii) "Cider Gum". In Baron von Muller's "Key" the popular name is also given as "Cider Gum". As said already, this is the species the Baron determined for me in 1885 as E. Gunnii; it is also the species which agrees nearest with the Baron's own description in his "Key", and it seems to agree with no other species described in the "Key"; [… … …]

Since I recieved the Baron's fresh determination I have written to him again and just casually mentioned that the species had been considered as likely to be new by two authorities in Sydney. I just mentioned the matter in such a way, as may induce him to examine his specimens once more. […]

It would also be very remarkable, supposing this Water Gum not to be E. Gunnii, that Baron von Muller should have made such a mistake in 1885 with a species which is so characteristic in its leaves, and then should have repeated the mistake in 1887 with the Bombala variety . […]
Not relevant.
